discussion.content: D is correct. The question is what "MOST likely will minimize the damage to a fileshare in this type of situation"? This is a ransomware attack. Although an IDS will not prevent the introduction of the malicious software to the host, it will alert at the HOST level (since the option says host-level IDS) hopefully BEFORE it spreads to the network shares...thus minimizing the impact on the network shares.

For writing reports, we need only 'write' permission, not 'write & execute'. The issue is that the user executed a file, so to minimize the damage (limit the damage) we should set granular permissions.

Sticking with D but the people who write these questions need to be fired. That said, no network is bullet proof and a company has to to assume there will be a breach of the network at some point regardless of the measures they take to prevent or limit access. The weakest link is always end users, so there needs to be plans/tools in place to limit the spread and mitigate damages once it happens.

Selected Answer: E
Per Messer: least privilege limits the scope of malicious behavior. 

Limits = Minimize

I'm going with A. Indication is the ransomware encrypts the file share not the entire server. I think there is to much assumption that the restore points would be encrypted as well. Restoral is often the best solution when dealing with ransomware.
Minimize = E

Now that's not going to protect you 100% so in the real world you would want to combine this with other factors (IDS/IPS, real time malware analysis, etc etc. but it is still the answer that gives us MOST protection out of the options given.
